addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

4 Octo
b
1591
. M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
The
Counsell of States
following the Campe.
Defeate in Daulphine./
Groninghen./

page.lettertext:
fol.72r
May it please yo
r
good L. Upon deli-
beration had between
e Assembly of the
states,
and
e Councel of state it is resol-
ved, that for
e better direction and coun-
tenance of all their actions at
e Campe,
the Councel shall transport themselves thither:
e rather upon
e hope that if this present
exploit against
Nieumeghen
shall be both
happely and speedely atchieved, they shall
have time and opportunitie, before
e harde
of
e winter, to besiege some other place.
This day we depart from
e Hage towardes
Tiel,
to reside ether there, or at
Arnham,
or in
e campe it self, as when we come
thither, we shall finde most behoofull for
e good of
e countrey. There is
intelligence come hither, that certaine cor-
nets of horse of
e quarters of
Guelders,
to
e nomber of seven, as we are informed,
ranging abroad in
e contrey of
Collen,
to
seeke a boutie, have encountred certaine En-
seignes of
e Enemie, about
Kerpen
whiche is
neere to Collen, and have defeated to the
nomber of 500 foote at
e lest, w
ch
were new-
ly levied for
e
D. of Parma
, and were
appointed to make there Rendevous at
Kerpen. The losse of o
rs
is six and thirty horse.
fol.72v
There are come hither from out of Italy two
yonge men, who passing thorowe Daulphine
homewarde, arrived there at
e same instant,
as
e
count Olivares
was defeated by
Mons
r
d'Esdignieres
; of w
ch
conflict I am persua-
ded
e report is come unto yo
w
. Because
e newes is good and they were present at
e service, I have sent yo
r
L. heerewith
suche special pointes, as being heere examined,
by order of
e Councel, they confesse upon
their knowledge. I am certainly
advertised by some,
at have spoken w
t
di-
vers of Groeninghen, that
e chiefest Ma-
gistrats of
e towne, who are Altogether
Spanishe, have attempted of late to erect
a sconce, before one of
e gates, and wea-
kest places of
e towne. Howbeit the com-
mons and confreries have opposed against
them, and have proceeded so farre in con-
tention together, as
e people tooke
at letter,
whiche I writte unto them a great while sins
and read it publickly in their meetinge:
and persuasions were used by some affecti-
onat to her
Ma
tie
at they should take an
other course, by rejecting
e Spaniard, and
cleaving to her Ma
tie
. But as it seemed they
were not willing to joine w
t
these Provinces
in any kinde of union, w
t
out her Ma
ties
protection.
fol.73r
I am but newly and somwhat rawly in-
formed heerof, by some
at knowe it to be
true, but not w
t
every circumstance. As
I shall heereafter be further advertised, and
as occasions are offered, I will negotiat
heerein for her Ma
ties
service. I have seene
from time to time most apparantly, that
both
Count William
and
e
states of Frise
,
were never well enclined, to have that
towne reduced and associat to
e rest, by
her Ma
ties
autoritie, for those jalouse conceats
that I have signified heeretofore. Otherwise
I make no doubt, but it might have bin ac-
complished. And though this present dis-
sention should continewe in
e towne, their
diffidence heere is alwaies suche, as I am
sure I shall be combred, to knowe howe to
deale, to make them take
e bene fi t, of those
passing good occasion. Howsoever it be,
I make account, so
at
e place may be reco-
vered by her Ma
tie
or by them, or in any other
sort, it is as muche as her Hignes will re-
quire for
at mater.
And thus I take my
humble leave. From
e Hage. Oc
t
4
1591.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
